content:
Should be fixable. Let‚Äôs take a look together. Here‚Äôs how we're going to try to to reattach your old Thunderbird profile:

Step 1. Find the old profile

You‚Äôve already done this, just do it agian and double-check that it contains the following: 

*   A Mail or ImapMail folder 
*   Files like prefs.js, key4.db, logins.json, abook.sqlite, etc.

(If that‚Äôs all there: Terrific. That‚Äôs your profile)


Step 2. Launch Thunderbird Profile Manager

Make sure Thunderbird is fully closed (no background processes).

Then Press Windows + R. type: thunderbird.exe -p. 

(and then press. Enter - this will open the profile manager)

Click Create Profile On the next screen, click ‚ÄúChoose Folder‚Ä¶‚Äù and browse to the exact folder on your other HDD that holds your old profile (this should be the folder that contains prefs.js, not one above it) Finish the setup 

In the list, select your new profile and check the box that should say something like ‚ÄúUse the selected profile without asking at startup‚Äù

Then Click Start Thunderbird

If everything is in the right place, Thunderbird should launch with all your old emails, settings, address book, etc. back.

ü§û

Let me know if the worked!
creator: Thundamike

content:
Sorry to hear that. But, there's a couple things to try here. Let‚Äôs roll up our sleeves and hopefully fix this for you.

1. Try compacting folders

  • Go to your email account > right-click a folder like Inbox or Trash > Compact. This cleans up ‚Äúdeleted‚Äù space and can improve speed - especially if it's been some time since this action was performed.

2. What kind of email account is this?

  • If it‚Äôs an IMAP account (like Gmail, Yahoo, Proton via Bridge, etc.), Thunderbird has to sync the deletion with the server. If the server is slow or there's a lot of back-and-forth, then that slow communication can cause delays.

3. Are you using Proton Mail with Proton Bridge?

  • Proton Bridge can sometimes slow down when handling bulk actions like deleting multiple messages, especially if Proton's under heavy load
creator: Thundamike

content: You could also just got to File -> Compact Folders and do all of them at once. But, where's the fun in that?
creator: Thundamike

content:
You were right to be suspicious, You definitely should not need to install an older version of Thunderbird to get your Outlook emails working.

Okie-doke, let‚Äôs roll up our sleeves and fix this. Since you're seeing the first message from your Outlook account but not the newer ones, let's try this first:

Confirm IMAP Setting in t-bird

  • Go to Account Settings in Thunderbird
  • Select your new Outlook account and check the 'Server Settings'
  • IMAP server settings should be: 
        *   imap-mail.outlook.com,          *  Port: 993,          *  SSL: SSL/TLS         *  Authentication Type = Normal Password (most likely)

Then go to Thunderbird -> Account Settings -> Edit Outgoing Server

  • smtp-mail.outlook.com,
  • Port: 587,
  • STARTTLS


Let me know if this helped!
creator: Thundamike
